start.title:
Calculated Rescue:

When Math Meets Maritime Disaster
start.description: February 1954, North Sea coast. A cargo vessel was lost in a raging storm. Three radio bearings and a handful of geometric principles were all we had to save twenty-seven lives. That night, Harbor Master Quinn showed me that mathematics wasn't just classroom theory—it was our most powerful tool in the race against time and tide.

S2_D1_F3_C0.heading: When Math Meets Maritime Disaster: Hands-On Math Exploration
S2_D1_F3_C0.body: Join Thomas Harlow at Blackrock Harbor as he learns to use Radio Direction Finding (RDF) equipment to locate the missing Meridian. Guide the ship's crew through taking precise bearing measurements, then apply triangulation and circle geometry to determine their exact position and plan an efficient rescue operation.

S3.S3_D1_F1_C1: What's happening, sir? I heard the emergency alarm.
S3.S3_D2_F2_C2: Distress call from the cargo vessel Meridian. She's caught in the storm somewhere in the North Sea.
S3.S3_D3_F3_C1: Do we have their coordinates?
S3.S3_D4_F4_C2: Fortunately, the Meridian still has radio contact with us. And they have Radio Direction Finding (RDF) equipment aboard. That will help them triangulate their position from three nearby radio beacons.
S3.S3_D5_F5_C3: Blackrock Control, this is First Officer Mitchell aboard the Meridian. We have our RDF equipment operational.
S3.S3_D6_F6_C1: How exactly will Sarah take those bearings, sir?
S3.S3_D7_F7_C2:
Good question, Thomas. Sarah will need to take bearings on three coastal radio beacons.
First, she'll tune to each beacon's frequency, then slowly rotate her directional antenna.
She'll look for the strongest signal, which will give us the bearing to that beacon.

about.heading: Radio Direction Finding Equipment
about.body:
The key principles demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Frequency Tuning: Radio Direction Finding requires precise tuning to the correct frequency for each beacon.
  2. Directional Antenna: A rotating directional antenna must be aligned with the signal source for maximum reception.
  3. Signal Strength: The strength of the received signal indicates how accurately the antenna is pointed toward the beacon.
  4. Bearing Measurement: The angle at which the antenna receives the strongest signal represents the bearing to the beacon.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Tune your radio to the correct frequency for each coastal beacon
  • Rotate the directional antenna to find the strongest signal
  • Record the bearing when signal strength reaches its peak
  • Collect bearings from all three beacons for triangulation

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
To take bearings using the RDF equipment:

  1. Select a beacon to work with (start with Beacon A)
  2. Tune the frequency dial to the beacon's frequency
    • Beacon A: 285 kHz
    • Beacon B: 315 kHz
    • Beacon C: 405 kHz
  3. Wait for the 'TUNED' indicator to appear
  4. Rotate the antenna direction slider to find the strongest signal
  5. When signal strength reaches 100%, click 'Lock Bearing'
  6. Repeat for all three beacons to complete the triangulation data

Tips for Success:

  • Watch the compass display to see your antenna direction
  • Monitor the signal strength meter for peak reception
  • Check the bearings log to track your progress

ui.strongSignalDetected: Strong signal detected! Click 'Lock Bearing' to record
ui.signalFound: Signal found. Rotate antenna to find the strongest signal peak.
ui.selectBeaconToBegin: Select a beacon to begin taking bearings.
ui.allBearingsCollected: All bearings collected! Excellent work, Sarah. Ready for triangulation.

accessibility.instructions: Radio Direction Finding Instructions for Screen Readers

accessibility.instructionStep2: Step 2: Use the frequency slider to tune to the beacon's correct frequency. The status will show 'TUNED' when properly adjusted.
accessibility.instructionStep3: Step 3: Use the antenna direction slider to rotate the antenna and find the strongest signal. Watch the signal strength meter.
accessibility.instructionStep4: Step 4: When signal strength reaches 100% (PEAK), click 'Record Bearing' to save the bearing measurement.

accessibility.beaconCompleted: This beacon bearing has already been recorded.
accessibility.beaconAvailable: Available to select for bearing measurement.
accessibility.beaconLocked: This beacon is locked until previous bearings are completed.
accessibility.frequencyHelp: Use arrow keys to adjust frequency in 5 kHz steps. Use Shift+arrows for 1 kHz fine adjustment. Page Up/Down for 25 kHz jumps.
accessibility.frequencyTuned: {{beacon}} successfully tuned to {{frequency}} {{unit}}. You may now adjust the antenna direction.
accessibility.antennaHelp: Use arrow keys to rotate antenna in 1 degree steps. Hold Shift for 0.5 degree fine adjustment, Ctrl for 5 degree coarse adjustment.
accessibility.signalStrengthMeter: Signal strength meter showing reception quality
accessibility.peakSignalFound: Peak signal found! You can now record this bearing.
accessibility.bearingRecorded: Bearing recorded for {{beacon}} at {{bearing}}{{degree}}. {{total}} bearings completed, {{remaining}} remaining.
accessibility.allBearingsComplete: All bearings successfully recorded! Triangulation data complete.
accessibility.lockBearingHelp: Click to record the current bearing measurement at peak signal strength.
accessibility.findPeakHelp: Rotate antenna to find peak signal strength before recording bearing.
accessibility.completedBearingsList: Complete list of all recorded bearings for triangulation

S4.S4_D1_F1_C2: Sarah, tune your radio to 285 kHz for Beacon A. Adjust your frequency dial until you get a clear signal.
S4.S4_D2_F2_C3: Tuning to 285 kHz... I'm getting a signal! Beacon A is coming through clearly now.
S4.S4_D3_F3_C2: Perfect. Now you need to rotate your directional antenna to find where that signal is strongest. The antenna will give you the strongest signal when it's aligned with Beacon A.
S4.S4_D4_F4_C2: At what bearing do you get the strongest signal from Beacon A?
S4.S4_D5_F5_C2: Excellent work, Sarah. That bearing tells us the direction from your position to Beacon A. Record that bearing.
S4.S4_D6_F6_C3: Bearing to Beacon A recorded at 42 degrees.
S4.S4_D7_F7_C1: So now we have one line from the ship pointing toward Beacon A?
S4.S4_D8_F8_C2: Precisely. But one line only tells us the ship is somewhere along this line. We need more bearings to pinpoint the location.
S4.S4_D9_F9_C2: Now for Beacon B, Sarah. Change frequency to 315 kHz. Same process—find the signal, then locate the direction of strongest reception.
S4.S4_D10_F10_C3: Beacon B signal acquired. Rotating antenna for Beacon B bearing... searching for the signal peak.
S4.S4_D11_F11_C2: Sarah, what bearing reading shows the peak signal strength for Beacon B?
S4.S4_D12_F12_C2: Outstanding. Record that second bearing.
S4.S4_D13_F13_C3: Second bearing recorded at 330 degrees. Two bearings complete.
S4.S4_D14_F14_C1: Now we have two lines that should intersect to show the ship's approximate position?
S4.S4_D15_F15_C2: The intersection of the lines would show their exact position, except RDF has quite a bit of error. A third bearing will give us much better accuracy.
S4.S4_D16_F16_C2: Final beacon, Sarah. Tune to Beacon C at 405 kHz. This third bearing will complete our triangulation data.
S4.S4_D17_F17_C3: Tuning to 405 kHz for Beacon C... The signal is strong. Ready for bearing sweep.
S4.S4_D18_F18_C2: Perfect. Find that signal peak and we'll have all three bearings needed for accurate position plotting.
S4.S4_D19_F19_C3: Rotating antenna for final bearing on Beacon C...
S4.S4_D20_F20_C2: What degrees does the antenna show for maximum signal strength for Beacon C?
S4.S4_D21_F21_C2: Excellent work, Sarah. Record that final bearing and transmit all three to us.
S4.S4_D22_F22_C3: Final bearing recorded at 82 degrees. Transmitting all bearings now.

S5.S5_D1_F1_C3:
Blackrock Control, this is Meridian. RDF bearings complete:
Beacon A at 42 degrees,
Beacon B at 330 degrees,
Beacon C at 82 degrees.
S5.S5_D2_F2_C2: Copy all bearings, Meridian. We now have the data needed to plot your position.
S5.S5_D3_F3_C1: So we'll plot these three bearing lines on our chart and see where they intersect?
S5.S5_D4_F4_C2: Each bearing line shows a direction from the ship to a known beacon location on the map. However, they won't exactly align—there is always some error and uncertainty. Instead, the lines will create a triangle — that's the area where the Meridian is most likely located.

about.heading: Radio Direction Finding Principles
about.body:
The key properties demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Bearing Lines: A bearing line shows the direction from which a radio signal is received, measured in degrees from true north.
  2. Triangulation Property: When three bearing lines are drawn from different stations, they should theoretically intersect at a single point.
  3. Triangle Formation: Due to measurement errors, the lines typically form a triangle rather than meeting at one point.
  4. Uncertainty Zone: This triangle represents the area where the vessel is most likely located.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Plot bearing lines from three coastal RDF stations
  • Observe how they intersect to form a triangle

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
To locate the vessel using triangulation:

  1. Plot the positions of the three RDF stations on the nautical chart
  2. Draw bearing lines from each station at the specified angles
    • Station A: 42°
    • Station B: 330°
    • Station C: 82°
  3. Observe where these lines intersect to form a triangle
  4. The vessel's position is most likely within this triangle

stage1.label: Set bearing for Station {label} ({bearing}°)
stage1.subLabel: Click on the pulsing station and set its bearing to exactly {bearing}°

stage2.label: Observe the 'Cocked Hat' triangle formed by the bearing lines

stage3.label: Calculate the area of the triangle using Heron's formula

accessibility.keyboardInstructions: Keyboard Navigation: Use Tab to navigate between stations. Press Enter or Space to select a station. Use arrow keys to adjust bearing angle. Press Enter to confirm bearing or Escape to cancel.
accessibility.stationInstructions: Use Tab to navigate between RDF stations. Press Enter or Space to select the current station for bearing adjustment.
accessibility.bearingInstructions: Use Up/Down arrow keys to adjust bearing angle. Press Enter to confirm or Escape to cancel. Current angle is announced as you adjust.
accessibility.chartDescription: Nautical chart showing RDF stations and bearing lines. Grid coordinates range from 0 to 10 nautical miles.
accessibility.stationDescription: RDF station with coordinates and bearing information. Click or press Enter to select for bearing adjustment.
accessibility.currentStationDescription: Current active station for bearing adjustment. Use arrow keys to adjust bearing angle.
accessibility.bearingLineDescription: Bearing line showing direction from station. Line extends to chart boundaries.
accessibility.angleDisplayDescription: Current bearing angle display. Shows degrees from true north.
accessibility.tableDescription: Station information table showing coordinates, target bearings, and current status.
accessibility.stationButtonLabel: Station {name} at coordinates ({x}, {y}). Target bearing: {bearing} degrees. {status}
accessibility.bearingAdjustmentLabel: Adjusting bearing for Station {name}. Current angle: {angle} degrees. Use arrow keys to adjust.
accessibility.confirmBearingLabel: Confirm bearing of {angle} degrees for Station {name}

S6.S6_D1_F1_C2:
I've marked the locations of our three coastal radio beacons on the chart. Sarah has given us bearings from the Meridian:
Beacon A at 42 degrees,
Beacon B at 330 degrees, and
Beacon C at 82 degrees.
Let's plot these and see what we've got.
S6.S6_D2_F2_C2: First, we need to plot the bearing lines from each beacon. The Meridian reported a bearing of 42 degrees to Beacon A.
S6.S6_D3_F3_C1: So we draw a line at 42 degrees from True North, passing through Beacon A's position?
S6.S6_D4_F4_C2: That's right. Let's start by plotting that line.
S6.S6_D5_F5_C2: Now let's add the bearing line for Beacon B. Sarah reported 330 degrees for Beacon B, so we draw a line at 330 degrees from True North, passing through Beacon B's position.
S6.S6_D6_F6_C1: I see... and once we have two bearing lines, they should intersect to show where the ship is located, right?
S6.S6_D7_F7_C2: In an ideal world, yes. But remember, Sarah was dealing with storm interference while taking these measurements. There will be small errors that affect our final result.
S6.S6_D8_F8_C2: Let's add our third bearing line. Sarah reported 82 degrees for Beacon C, so we draw a line at 82 degrees from True North, passing through Beacon C's position.
S6.S6_D9_F9_C1: With three bearing lines, we should be able to get a better fix on the Meridian's position.
S6.S6_D10_F10_C2: Exactly. Three bearing lines give us redundancy and confirmation. In marine navigation, having multiple sources of information means we're not relying on just one measurement that could be wrong. It's like double-checking your work, but in this case, it could save lives.

S7.S7_D1_F1_C2: We've constructed a triangle from the three bearing lines. The Meridian is somewhere inside it, but that area is still too large for a precise search.
S7.S7_D2_F2_C1: Right. We need a smarter way to narrow down the search area.
S7.S7_D3_F3_C2:
Exactly. We'll use geometry — specifically two circles — to define our next search zones.
One will pass through all three vertices of the triangle. That's called a Circumscribed Circle.
The other will touch each side once. That's called an Inscribed Circle. Each offers a different strategy.
S7.S7_D4_F4_C1: So this step is about deciding which circle gives us the best chance of finding the ship quickly.

about.heading: Circle Properties in Triangle Geometry
about.body:
The key properties demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Circumscribed Circle: A circle that passes through all three vertices of a triangle.
  2. Perpendicular Bisector Property: Any point on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment is equidistant from both endpoints.
  3. Circumcenter: The point where all three perpendicular bisectors of a triangle's sides intersect.
  4. Inscribed Circle: A circle that touches all three sides of a triangle.
  5. Angle Bisector Property: Any point on an angle bisector is equidistant from the two sides that form the angle.
  6. Incenter: The point where all three angle bisectors of a triangle's angles intersect.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Construct perpendicular bisectors to find the circumcenter
  • Construct angle bisectors to find the incenter
  • Calculate the radii of both circles using geometric formulas
  • Compare the areas of both circles to understand search efficiency

Mathematical Relationship Properties When comparing circumscribed and inscribed circles:

  • The circumscribed circle always contains the inscribed circle
  • The circumscribed circle is always larger than the inscribed circle
  • The ratio between their areas depends on the triangle's shape
  • Both circles share the same geometric relationship to the triangle regardless of the triangle's size

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
To determine optimal search areas:

  1. For the circumscribed circle:
    • Construct perpendicular bisectors for each side of the triangle
    • Find the circumcenter where these bisectors intersect
    • Use the 'Measure Radius' button to find the radius
    • This circle passes through all vertices of the triangle
  2. For the inscribed circle:
    • Construct angle bisectors for each angle of the triangle
    • Find the incenter where these bisectors intersect
    • Use the 'Measure Radius' button to find the radius
    • This circle touches all sides of the triangle
  3. Understanding the comparison:
    • The circumscribed circle provides maximum search coverage
    • The inscribed circle offers more focused search coverage
    • The circumscribed circle covers approximately 4.8× more area than the inscribed circle
    • Choose based on your search strategy and available resources

translations.ariaLabel: This is a nautical navigation chart with a coordinate grid showing nautical miles from 3 to 10. The chart displays a triangle formed by three points: P at coordinates (5.01, 5.45), Q at coordinates (7.19, 7.87), and R at coordinates (3.88, 7.4). The triangle shows side lengths of 3.26, 3.34, and 2.25 nautical miles respectively with an area of 3.49 square nautical miles.

points.intersection: Forms at the intersection of all three perpendicular bisectors
points.equidistant: Is equidistant from all three vertices of the triangle
points.center: Becomes the center of the circumscribed circle

circumscribedCircle.title: Circumscribed Circle

incenter.description: The point where all angle bisectors meet is the incenter.

inscribedCircle.description: The inscribed circle touches each side of the triangle exactly once.

S8.S8_D1_F1_C2: First, we need to construct perpendicular bisectors for each side of our triangle. A perpendicular bisector passes through the midpoint of a side and forms a 90-degree angle with it.
S8.S8_D2_F2_C1: And why are perpendicular bisectors important for finding the circumscribed circle?
S8.S8_D3_F3_C2: Any point on a perpendicular bisector is equidistant from both endpoints of the side. So the point where all three perpendicular bisectors meet is equidistant from all three vertices of our triangle—making it the perfect center for our circle.
S8.S8_D4_F4_C1: I see. So let's draw these perpendicular bisectors and find where they intersect.
S8.S8_D5_F5_C2: Now can you see where the three perpendicular bisectors intersect?
S8.S8_D6_F6_C1: This point is the circumcenter—the center of our circumscribed circle.
S8.S8_D7_F7_C1: And that circle will pass through all three vertices of our triangle, right? Because the circumcenter is equidistant from all three points.
S8.S8_D8_F8_C1: I can see the circumscribed circle is drawn on the chart now. What's our next step?
S8.S8_D9_F9_C2: Good observation, Thomas. We need to determine the exact radius measurement for our search planning.
S8.S8_D10_F10_C2: Use the 'Measure Radius' button on the interactive to find the radius of our circumscribed circle.
S8.S8_D11_F11_C2: What is the radius of the circumscribed circle for our triangular search area?
S8.S8_D12_F12_C2: Excellent. Now we have our first potential search area—a circle with radius 1.75 NM centered at the circumcenter.
S8.S8_D13_F13_C1: So this circle completely covers our uncertainty triangle and passes through all three vertices?
S8.S8_D14_F14_C2: Exactly right, Thomas. That's what makes it our maximum possible search area.
S8.S8_D15_F15_C2: Now let's explore our second option—the inscribed circle. To find its center, we need to construct the angle bisectors of our triangle.
S8.S8_D16_F16_C1: Angle bisectors? Those divide each angle into two equal parts, correct?
S8.S8_D17_F17_C2: Yes. An angle bisector divides an angle into two equal parts. The interesting property of angle bisectors is that any point on an angle bisector is equidistant from the two sides that form the angle.
S8.S8_D18_F18_C1: So the point where all three angle bisectors meet would be equidistant from all three sides of our triangle.
S8.S8_D19_F19_C2: Precisely. That point is called the incenter, and it will be the center of our inscribed circle.
S8.S8_D20_F20_C2: Here we can see the three angle bisectors and where they intersect—that's our incenter.
S8.S8_D21_F21_C1: And the inscribed circle will touch each side of the triangle exactly once, right?
S8.S8_D22_F22_C2: That's correct. The radius of this circle will be the perpendicular distance from the incenter to any side of the triangle.
S8.S8_D23_F23_C1: Now I can see the inscribed circle touching each side of our triangle. This one looks much smaller than the circumscribed circle.
S8.S8_D24_F24_C2: Sharp observation, Thomas. Let's get the exact measurement using the 'Measure Radius' button for the inscribed circle.
S8.S8_D25_F25_C2: What is the radius of the inscribed circle for our triangular search area?
S8.S8_D26_F26_C1: 0.79 NM - that's significantly smaller than our circumscribed circle.
S8.S8_D27_F27_C2: Exactly right. That size difference will be crucial for our search strategy decision.
S8.S8_D29_F29_C2: Now we need to compare the sizes of our two search areas to determine the most efficient search strategy.
S8.S8_D30_F30_C1: I know the area of a circle is calculated using the formula A = π × r².
S8.S8_D31_F31_C2: Exactly. Let's calculate and compare the areas of both circles to see the difference in search coverage.
S8.S8_D32_F32_C2: The area of a circle is calculated using the formula A = π × r². If the circumscribed circle has a radius of 1.75 NM and the inscribed circle has a radius of 0.79 NM, how much larger is the area of the circumscribed circle compared to the inscribed circle?
S8.S8_D33_F33_C1: For the circumscribed circle, we get π × 1.75² = 9.6 NM². And for the inscribed circle, we get π × 0.79² = 2.0 NM².
S8.S8_D34_F34_C1: Dividing these areas, 9.6 / 2.0 = 4.8, so the circumscribed circle is 4.8 times larger than the inscribed circle.
S8.S8_D35_F35_C2: Good. This difference is crucial for our search strategy.
S8.S8_D36_F36_C1: So which one should we use? The larger circumscribed circle guarantees we'll cover all possible locations, but the smaller inscribed circle would be much more efficient to search.
S8.S8_D37_F37_C2: This is where probability comes into play. The vessel is most likely near the center of our uncertainty triangle, which the inscribed circle covers. However, we can't rule out the possibility that it's closer to the vertices.

S9.S9_D1_F0_C1: So if we start our search in the Inscribed Circle, we have a higher chance of finding the Meridian faster.
S9.S9_D2_F1_C2: And if we don't find them in the Inscribed Circle, we can expand our search to the Circumscribed Circle.
S9.S9_D3_F1_C2:
[Several hours later]
Well, Thomas, the Meridian is safely under tow heading back to harbor. They should arrive by dawn.
S9.S9_D4_F2_C1: I never thought geometry would be the key to saving lives at sea. Those lives were saved by triangles, perpendicular bisectors, and angle bisectors.
S9.S9_D5_F3_C2: Indeed. Mathematics isn't just academic—it's a practical tool for maritime rescue. Now, let's prepare for the Meridian's arrival.

quest_completion.subheading: Calculated Rescue: When Math Meets Maritime Disaster
quest_completion.content:
You successfully completed the Calculated Rescue STEAMQuest.

  • You used triangulation to convert bearing lines into a defined search area
  • You constructed circumscribed and inscribed circles to optimize search strategy

Keep exploring how mathematical principles can enhance maritime safety and rescue operations!

triangulation.definition: Triangulation is a method to determine the location of a point by measuring angles to it from known points at either end of a fixed baseline.

bearing.definition: Bearing is a line drawn on a chart showing the direction from which a signal is coming, measured in degrees from true north.

bearings.definition: Bearings are a line drawn on a chart showing the direction from which a signal is coming, measured in degrees from true north.

cocked_hat_triangle.definition: Cocked Hat Triangle is an area of uncertainty formed when three bearing lines don't meet at a single point due to measurement errors.

herons_formula.definition: Heron's Formula is a formula that calculates the area of a triangle using the lengths of its three sides: Area = √(s(s − a)(s − b)(s − c)), where s is the semi-perimeter.

semi_perimeter.definition: Semi-perimeter is half the perimeter of a triangle, calculated by adding all three sides and dividing by 2.

perpendicular_bisector.definition: Perpendicular Bisector is a line that passes through the midpoint of a line segment at a right angle (90 degrees).

circumscribed_circle.definition: Circumscribed Circle is the circle with center where the perpendicular bisectors of a triangle's sides intersect. It's center is equidistant from all three vertices.

circumcenter.definition: Circumcenter is the point where the perpendicular bisectors of a triangle's sides intersect, equidistant from all three vertices.

inscribed_circle.definition: Inscribed Circle is a circle that touches each side of a triangle exactly once, with its center at the incenter.

incenter.definition: Incenter is the point where the angle bisectors of a triangle intersect, equidistant from all three sides.

angle_bisector.definition: Angle Bisector is a line that divides an angle into two equal parts.

resultant_force.definition: Resultant Force is the single force that has the same effect as two or more forces applied together.

vector_addition.definition: Vector Addition is the method of combining two or more vectors (quantities with both magnitude and direction) to find their resultant.

law_of_cosines.definition: Law of Cosines is a formula used to find unknown parts of a triangle when two sides and the included angle (or three sides) are known: c2 = a2 + b2 − 2ab · cos(C).

magnitude.definition: Magnitude is the size or absolute value of a quantity, regardless of its direction.

rdf.definition: RDF (Radio Direction Finding) is a navigation technique that uses specialized radio equipment to determine the direction from which a radio signal is coming, measured as a bearing in degrees from true north.

radio_direction_finding.definition: Radio Direction Finding is a navigation technique that uses specialized radio equipment to determine the direction from which a radio signal is coming, measured as a bearing in degrees from true north.

common.thomas_description: A young Black man in a dark naval uniform with gold buttons, holding a rolled document and looking confident.
common.quinn_description: An older man with a white beard wearing a navy captain's uniform with gold-emblemed cap, holding an open logbook.
common.sarah_description: A focused woman in a storm-weathered with officer's uniform, adjusting a directional antenna while relaying bearings over the radio with calm precision.
common.bg1_description: Stormy harbor at night with snow, docked boats, and a lighthouse in the distance. The tension of the storm is palpable.
common.bg2_description: Warm-lit interior of a wooden radio room with snowy windows, creating a contrast of coziness and urgency.
common.bg3_description: Detailed strategy/planning office with world maps, compasses, and naval tools—ideal for tactical discussions.
common.bg4_description: Another communications room focused on navigation and transmission equipment, facing a wall of snowy windows.
common.bg5_description: Early morning at the harbor as the storm calms; people watch the ship return at sunrise—symbolizing rescue and relief.
common.bg6_description: Dimly-lit ship bridge interior full of controls and glowing radar during a storm. Ideal for tense shipboard communication scenes.
common.bg7_description: Raging sea with lightning and massive waves hitting the deck — perfect for showcasing the chaos the Meridian faces during the storm.
common.invalid_pair: Invalid Pair! Try a different combination of angles
common.focusModeAnnouncement: Please toggle to focus mode to select angles and drop them in the correct locations.
